translated: MahÄyÄna Abhidharma Compendium Treatise, Fascicle 1
Composed by Bodhisattva Asaá¹…ga
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order
The main topics and decisive analysis each have four kinds,
The three dharmas subsume what should be accomplished, the truths, dharmas, attainment, and treatises.
How many, what causes, characteristics, establishment, and sequence,
Meaning and analogies are extensively distinguished, the compendium's summary verses should be known.
How many aggregates, realms, and sense bases are there?
There are five aggregates, namely the form aggregate, feeling aggregate, perception aggregate, formation aggregate, and consciousness aggregate.

There are eighteen realms, namely the eye realm, form realm, eye-consciousness realm, ear realm, sound realm, ear-consciousness realm, nose realm, smell realm, nose-consciousness realm, tongue realm, taste realm, tongue-consciousness realm, body realm, tactile realm, body-consciousness realm, mind realm, dharma realm, and mind-consciousness realm.

There are twelve bases, namely, the eye base and form base, the ear base and sound base, the nose base and smell base, the tongue base and taste base, the body base and tangible object base, and the thought base and dharma base.
Why are the aggregates only five?

In order to reveal the five kinds of things that constitute a self, namely, the things that constitute the body, the things that constitute enjoyment, the things that constitute speech, the things that constitute the self's making of dharmas and non-dharmas, and the things that constitute the self's own body which is the basis of the above four.
Why are the elements only eighteen?
Because the body and so forth are able to hold the nature of enjoyment of the six activities of the past and present.
Why are the bases only twelve?
Only because the body is able to serve as the door for the arising and growth of the enjoyment of the six activities of the future.
Why are they called the appropriated aggregates?
They are called the appropriated aggregates because they are combined with appropriation.
What is appropriation?
It refers to the desire and greed within the aggregates.
Why is desire and greed called appropriation?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Because it can attract future and present aggregates and not abandon them, the desire for the future and attachment to the present is called grasping.
Why are the realms and bases called dharmas with grasping?
They should be explained like the aggregates.
What are the characteristics of the form aggregate?
The characteristic of form is that of transformation and manifestation.
This is of two kinds:
one is that which is transformed and destroyed by contact, and the other is that which is manifested in terms of location.
What is meant by that which is transformed and destroyed by contact?
When it is contacted by hands, feet, clods, stones, knives, sticks, cold, heat, hunger, thirst, mosquitoes, gadflies, snakes, and scorpions, it is immediately transformed and destroyed.
What is meant by that which is manifested in terms of location?
It is that which can be manifested in terms of location as such and such form, such and such form;
or that which is variously imagined in accordance with the characteristics of the concentrated mind or the non-concentrated mind.
What are the characteristics of the feeling aggregate?
The characteristic of feeling is that of sensation. It is because of feeling that one senses the various results of pure and impure actions.
What is the characteristic of the aggregate of conceptualization?

The characteristic of conceptualization is that of constructing images. Because of conceptualization, one constructs and imagines various images of things, and according to what one sees, hears, recognizes, and knows, one gives rise to various kinds of speech.
What is the characteristic of the aggregate of karmic forces?
The characteristic of the aggregate of karmic forces is that of creating. Because of karmic forces, the mind creates and engages in good, bad, and indeterminate categories, and thus drives the mind.
What is the characteristic of the aggregate of consciousness?
The characteristic of consciousness is that of discriminating. Because of consciousness, one discriminates various objects such as forms, sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, and mental objects.
What is the characteristic of the eye element?

The characteristic of the eye element is that which the eye has seen, is seeing, or will see forms, as well as the seeds of these accumulated in the consciousness that is the result of maturation, the Älaya consciousness.
The characteristics of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind elements are also like this.
What is the characteristic of the form element?
The characteristic of the form element is that which the eye has seen, is seeing, or will see, and with regard to which the eye element has or will have dominance.
The characteristics of the sound, smell, taste, tactile object, and dharma elements are also like this.
What are the characteristics of the eye consciousness element?
It is the eye's similar and immediately antecedent condition, the form that is its dominant condition, and the eye consciousness that arises in dependence on them.
The characteristics of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness elements should be understood in the same way.
What are the characteristics of the sense bases?
They should be understood according to the elements, as appropriate.
How is the form aggregate established?
It is all form, whether the four great elements or the form derived from the four great elements.
What are the four great elements?
They are the earth element, water element, fire element, and wind element.
What is the earth element?
It is the quality of solidity and hardness.
What is the water element?
It is the quality of fluidity and moisture.
What is the fire element?
It is the quality of heat and warmth.
What is the wind element?
It is the quality of lightness and movement.
What is form derived from the four great elements?
Namely, the eye faculty, ear faculty, nose faculty, tongue faculty, and body faculty, part of form, sound, smell, taste, and the form included in the mental object realm.
What is the eye faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis for eye consciousness, which is produced from the four great elements.
What is the ear faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis for ear consciousness, which is produced from the four great elements.
What is the nose faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis for nose consciousness, which is produced from the four great elements.
What is the tongue faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis for tongue consciousness, which is produced from the four great elements.
What is the body faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis for body consciousness, which is produced from the four great elements.
What is form?

It is the object of activity of the eye faculty, which is derived from the four great elements, such as blue, yellow, red, white, long, short, square, round, coarse, fine, high, low, regular, irregular, light, shadow, brightness, darkness, clouds, smoke, dust, mist, distant color, shape color, and empty color.
It is also of three kinds: beautiful, ugly, and neither.
What is sound?

It is the object grasped by the ear faculty, which is derived from the four great elements, which may be agreeable, disagreeable, or neither, which may have as its cause the great elements that are appropriated, the great elements that are not appropriated, or both, which may be established by worldly consensus, produced by accomplishment, or imagined, which may be included in the words of the sages or not included in the words of the sages.
What is smell?
It is the object perceived by the nose faculty, which is derived from the four great elements, namely good smells, bad smells, neutral smells, natural smells, mixed smells, and changed smells.
What are tastes?

It is the object perceived by the tongue faculty, which is derived from the four great elements, namely bitter, sour, sweet, pungent, salty, and bland, or agreeable, disagreeable, or neutral, or natural, mixed, or changed.
What is part of the tangible?

It is the object perceived by the body faculty, which is derived from the four great elements, namely smoothness, roughness, lightness, heaviness, softness, slowness, quickness, cold, hunger, thirst, fullness, strength, weakness, exhaustion, itching, stickiness, disease, aging, death, fatigue, rest, and vigor.
What is form included in the dharma-realm?

There are five kinds that should be known, namely, extremely subtle form, extremely distant form, form produced by volition, form produced by imagination, and form produced by the mastery of concentration.
How is the aggregate of feeling established?
It refers to the six groups of feeling:

Feeling produced by eye contact, feeling produced by ear contact, feeling produced by nose contact, feeling produced by tongue contact, feeling produced by body contact, and feeling produced by mind contact.
These six groups of feeling are either pleasant, painful, or neither painful nor pleasant.
There are also pleasant bodily feeling, painful bodily feeling, and neither painful nor pleasant bodily feeling.
Pleasant mental feeling, painful mental feeling, and neither painful nor pleasant mental feeling.
There are also pleasant feeling with taste, painful feeling with taste, and neither painful nor pleasant feeling with taste.
Pleasant feeling without taste, painful feeling without taste, and neither painful nor pleasant feeling without taste.
There are also pleasant feelings that are based on indulgence, painful feelings that are based on indulgence, and neither painful nor pleasant feelings that are based on indulgence.
There are pleasant feelings that are based on renunciation, painful feelings that are based on renunciation, and neither painful nor pleasant feelings that are based on renunciation.
What are bodily feelings?
They are feelings associated with the five consciousnesses.
What are mental feelings?
They are feelings associated with mental consciousness.
What are feelings with a sense of taste?
They are feelings associated with craving for one's own body.
What are feelings without a sense of taste?
They are feelings not associated with that craving.
What are feelings based on indulgence?
They are feelings associated with craving for the five kinds of exquisite sensual pleasures.
What are feelings based on renunciation?
They are feelings not associated with that craving.
How is the aggregate of conceptualization established?
It is the six groups of conceptualization:

Conceptualization born from eye contact, conceptualization born from ear contact, conceptualization born from nose contact, conceptualization born from tongue contact, conceptualization born from body contact, and conceptualization born from mind contact.

Due to this conceptualization, one may cognize with characteristics, or cognize without characteristics, or cognize as small, or cognize as large, or cognize as immeasurable, or cognize as having no more to learn, or cognize as the sphere of nothingness.
What is conceptualization with characteristics?
It refers to all conceptualizations other than the conceptualizations of unwholesome speech, the sphere of non-conceptualization, and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
What is conceptualization without characteristics?
It refers to the remaining conceptualizations.
What is conceptualization of the small?
It refers to conceptualization that cognizes the desire realm.
What is conceptualization of the large?
It refers to conceptualization that cognizes the form realm.
What is conceptualization of the immeasurable?
It refers to conceptualization that cognizes the sphere of infinite space and the sphere of infinite consciousness.
What is conceptualization of having no more to learn, the sphere of nothingness?
It refers to conceptualization that cognizes the sphere of nothingness.
How is the aggregate of formations established?
It refers to the six groups of volition:

The intention produced by eye contact, the intention produced by ear contact, the intention produced by nose contact, the intention produced by tongue contact, the intention produced by body contact, and the intention produced by mind contact.
Because of this intention, one intends to do good, one intends to become defiled, one intends to make distinctions in states.

Moreover, this intention, excluding feeling and conceptualization, together with the other mental factors and factors not directly associated with the mind, is generally called the aggregate of mental formations.
What are called the other mental factors?

Namely, attention, contact, desire, resolve, mindfulness, concentration, wisdom, faith, shame, conscience, non-greed, non-hatred, non-delusion, effort, tranquility, heedfulness, equanimity, non-harming, greed, hatred, conceit, ignorance, doubt, the view of the aggregates as a person, extreme views, the view of holding a view as paramount, the view of holding mere rules and rituals as paramount, wrong view, anger, resentment, hypocrisy, malice, envy, stinginess, deceit, flattery, arrogance, harmfulness, shamelessness, lack of conscience, torpor, restlessness, lack of faith, laziness, heedlessness, forgetfulness, incorrect knowledge, distraction, sleep, regret, investigation, and analysis.
What is volition?
It is that which creates mental activity, whose nature is to direct the mind towards good, bad, or neutral things. Its function is to engage the mind.
What is attention?
It is that which activates the mind, whose nature is to hold the mind to an object. Its function is to maintain the mind on an object.
What is contact?

It is said that the essence of this [faculty] is the discrimination that arises from the transformation of the various faculties in the union of the three [conditions], and its activity is to serve as the support for feeling.
What is desire?
It is the desire to engage in and accomplish what is pleasing, and its nature is that of hoping for something. Its activity is that of serving as the support for right effort.
What is resolve?
It is the firm grasping of a determined object, and its nature is that of being unmoved. Its activity is that of being unshakable.
What is memory?
It is the clear recollection of familiar things, and its nature is that of not forgetting. Its activity is that of not being distracted.
What is samÄdhi?
It is the one-pointedness of mind on a contemplated object, and its nature is that of being the support for knowledge.
Its activity is that of serving as the support for knowledge.
What is wisdom?
It is the discernment of dharmas with regard to a contemplated object, and its nature is that of eliminating doubt.
What is faith?
It is the pure desire for something real, virtuous, and able, and its nature is that of being the support for aspiration.
What is conscience?
Its nature is that of feeling ashamed of oneâ€™s own faults, and its activity is that of supporting the cessation of evil conduct.
What is shame?
Its nature is that of feeling ashamed of oneâ€™s faults before others, and its activity is that of supporting the cessation of evil conduct, as explained above.
What is noncovetousness?
Its nature is that of being free from attachment to existence and the instruments of existence, and its activity is that of supporting the cessation of evil conduct.
What is nonhatred?
Its nature is that of being free from hatred toward the suffering and the instruments of suffering of sentient beings, and its activity is that of supporting the cessation of evil conduct.
What is nondelusion?
Its nature is that of being the discernment that results from retribution, teaching, and realization, and its activity is that of supporting the cessation of evil conduct.
What is vigor?

Its nature is that of mental courage, and its activity is that of perfecting the good qualities by donning armor, by exertion, by being without dejection, by being without regression, and by being without satisfaction.
What is tranquility?
Its nature is that of the repose of the grossness and weakness of body and mind and the pliancy of body and mind, and its activity is that of eliminating all obstacles.
What is non-negligence?

It is based on right effort, non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion, cultivating wholesome dharmas, and guarding the mind against defiled dharmas. Its nature is to perfect all worldly and supramundane blessings. Its activity is to serve as the basis for non-negligence.
What is equanimity?

It is based on right effort, non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion, opposing the state of defilement, the nature of the mind being impartial, the nature of the mind being upright, and the nature of the mind abiding without effort. Its nature is to be the basis for not allowing defilements. Its activity is to serve as the basis for not allowing defilements.
What is non-harming?
It is the part of the wholesome roots of non-hatred, the mind being compassionate. Its nature is not to harm. Its activity is not to harm.
What is greed?
It is the love of the three realms. Its nature is to give rise to various sufferings.
What is hatred?
It is the mind being angry towards sentient beings, suffering, and the conditions of suffering. Its nature is to abide unhappily and to be the basis for misconduct.
What is pride?
Its nature is that of mental haughtiness that is based on the view of a real self, and its activity is that of supporting the arising of disrespect and suffering.
What is ignorance?
Its nature is that of non-knowing of the three realms, and its activity is that of supporting the arising of false decisions, doubts, and defiled activities with regard to things;
What is doubt?
Its nature is that of uncertainty with regard to the truths, and its activity is that of supporting the non-production of good.
What is the view of a real self?
Its nature is that of acquiescence, desire, discernment, and views that arise from the five grasping heaps, and its activity is that of supporting all false views.
What is the view that grasps an extreme?
Its nature is that of acquiescence, desire, discernment, and views that arise from the five grasping heaps, and its activity is that of obstructing the middle way and the escape from samsara.

What is the grasping of views? It means to consider and grasp as the most, as the best, as superior, and as wonderful, the views and the five aggregates that are the basis of views, and to consider and grasp as the most, as the best, as superior, and as wonderful, the five aggregates that are the basis of views. Its nature is that of acquiescence, desire, discernment, and views. Its activity is that of serving as the support for false views.
What is the grasping of morality and vows?

It means to consider and grasp as pure, as liberation, and as escape, morality and vows and the five aggregates that are the basis of morality and vows, and to consider and grasp as pure, as liberation, and as escape, the five aggregates that are the basis of morality and vows. Its nature is that of acquiescence, desire, discernment, and views. Its activity is that of serving as the support for fruitless toil.
What is wrong views?

It means to deny causes and results, to deny function, to destroy real events, and to have wrong discrimination. Its nature is that of acquiescence, desire, discernment, and views. Its activity is that of severing good roots, of serving as the support for the solidification of unwholesome roots, of causing the arising of the unwholesome, and of preventing the arising of the wholesome.ğŸ”½How many of these five views are views that add?
How many are views that subtract?
The fourth is the view of augmentation, because it augments the self-nature and distinctions of the known objects, and because it augments the foremost and purity among the various views.
One part is mostly the view of diminution.
As for the various views concerning the past and future, which of these five views do they belong to?
It is said that they belong to two or all of them.
As for the various views concerning the indeterminate, which of these five views do they belong to?
It is said that they belong to two or all of them.
For what faults did the Blessed One observe, and in the aggregates, realms, and bases, did he repudiate the grasping of self with five aspects?

Because he observed that those who grasp the view of the aggregates have five kinds of faults, namely the fault of difference, the fault of impermanence, the fault of non-independence, the fault of having no body, and the fault of liberation without effort.

There are twenty kinds of satkÄya views regarding the five appropriated aggregates. Namely, regarding form, one thinks, It is me, I have form, Form belongs to me, I am in form. Similarly, regarding feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, one thinks, It is me, I have consciousness, Consciousness belongs to me, I am in consciousness.
Among these views, how many are views of self?
How many are views of what belongs to self?
Five are views of self, fifteen are views of what belongs to self.
For what reason are the fifteen views of what belongs to self?
Because of being associated with what belongs to self, because of being subordinate to what belongs to self, because of not being apart from what belongs to self.
Should satkÄya views be said to be about things that are known or unknown?
They should be said to be about things that are not ascertained, like mistakenly perceiving a rope as a snake.
What is anger?
It is one part of aversion towards present harm, with the nature of mental rage, whose function is to serve as the basis for grasping a stick and becoming agitated.
What is resentment?
That is, from this point on, it is a part of anger, and its nature is that of harboring resentment and not letting go of it. Its activity is that of providing a basis for lack of patience.
What is DECEIT ?

When oneâ€™s own faults are being revealed, it is a part of delusion, and its nature is that of concealing oneâ€™s faults. Its activity is that of providing a basis for remorse and for not being at peace.
What is MALICE ?

It is a part of anger, and its nature is that of a mind that is intractable, arising from resentment and rage. Its activity is that of providing a basis for being rude and violent and for not acquiring merit, for not being at peace, and for not being happy.
What is ENVY ?

It is a part of anger, and its nature is that of a mind that is jealous, arising from attachment to gain and respect and from intolerance of othersâ€™ good qualities and good reputation. Its activity is that of obstructing nonenvy and of causing a mind of anxiety and unhappiness.
What is AVARICE ?

It is a part of craving, and its nature is that of a mind that is stingy, arising from attachment to gain and respect and to the enjoyments of life. Its activity is that of obstructing nonavarice and of causing a mind of attachment and not letting go.
What is HYPOCRISY ?
It is a part of craving and delusion, and its nature is that of deceitfully displaying unreal merits, and its activity is that of serving as the support for wrong livelihood.
What is HYPOCRISY ?
It is a part of craving and delusion, and its nature is that of deceitfully contriving expedient means to conceal ones real faults, and its activity is that of obstructing correct instruction.
What is SELF-IMPORTANCE ?

It is a part of craving, and its nature is that of a delight in the mind due to the characteristics of youth, health, and longevity, or to the acquisition of any of the impure honors and benefits of saá¹ƒsÄra, and its activity is that of serving as the support for all passions and secondary passions.
What is HARMFULNESS ?
It is a part of hatred, and its nature is that of lack of pity, lack of compassion, and lack of mercy, and its activity is that of injuring sentient beings.
What is SHAMELESSNESS ?
It is a part of craving, hatred, and delusion, and its nature is that of lack of shame in ones own faults, and its activity is that of supporting all passions and secondary passions.
What is STUPIDITY ?
It is a part of craving, hatred, and delusion. Its nature is that of not being ashamed of faults in relation to others. Its activity is that of assisting all passions and secondary passions.
What is torpor?
It is a part of delusion. Its nature is that of a lack of alertness of mind. Its activity is that of obstructing the discernment of dharmas.
What is agitation?
It is a part of craving. Its nature is that of a lack of tranquility of mind that is distracted by following after impure things. Its activity is that of obstructing calming.
What is lack of faith?
It is a part of delusion. Its nature is that of a lack of clarity, purity, and aspiration of mind in regard to the merits of the Three Treasures. Its activity is that of supporting laziness.
What is laziness?

It is a part of delusion. Its nature is that of a lack of mental exertion in regard to the wholesome due to attachment to the pleasure of sleep and rest. Its activity is that of obstructing the practice of wholesome dharmas.
What is heedlessness?

It is by nature noncultivation of good states on the basis of indolence and craving, ill-will, and ignorance, and its activity is that of obstructing cultivation and acting as the support of demeritorious states.
What is forgetfulness?
It is by nature memory associated with the passions, and its activity is that of acting as a support for distraction.
What is non-alertness?
It is by nature discernment associated with the passions, and its activity is that of giving rise to non-alertness of body, speech, and mind and acting as a support for transgression.
What is distraction? It is by nature the scattering of the mind on the side of craving, ill-will, and ignorance.
It is of six kinds: distraction by nature, external distraction, internal distraction, distraction by characteristics, distraction of grossness, and distraction of attention.
What is distraction by nature?
It is the five consciousnesses.
What is external distraction?
It is the scattering of the mind to the five objects of desire when one is cultivating the good.
What is internal distraction?
That is, when one is cultivating wholesome [activities], one is immersed in sinking, floating, and indulging in [those states].
What is distraction of characteristics?
That is, for the sake of others' faith and respect, one falsely displays the cultivation of wholesome [activities].
What is distraction of coarseness?

That is, relying on the power of coarseness belonging to the category of grasping at I and mine and the conceit of I, when cultivating wholesome dharmas, one gives rise to the grasping at I and mine and the conceit of I in relation to all the feelings that have arisen, and mixes up the grasping of characteristics.
What is distraction of attention?
That is, relying on other vehicles and other concentrations, whether relying on them or entering into them, all the distractions that can obstruct the attainment of detachment.
What is sleepiness?

That is, based on the causes and conditions of sleepiness, it is a part of delusion, with the essence of the mind's contraction, which may be wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate, may be timely or untimely, may be appropriate or inappropriate, and has the function of causing the loss of what can be done and becoming the basis [for further actions].
What is remorse?

That is, it is based on what should be done and what should not be done, what is appropriate and what is inappropriate. It is a part of delusion, with mental regret as its essence. It can be wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate, timely or untimely, appropriate or inappropriate, and its activity is to obstruct the abiding of the mind.
What is called investigation?
That is, based on thought or wisdom, it investigates verbal expressions, causing the mind to turn coarsely.
What is called analysis?
That is, based on thought or wisdom, it examines verbal expressions, causing the mind to turn subtly.
These two have the activity of being the basis for abiding in comfort or discomfort.

Moreover, the wholesome mental factors have the activity of eliminating their own objects of abandonment, while the afflictions and secondary afflictions have the activity of obstructing their own antidotes.
What are called factors not directly associated with mind?

Namely, acquisition, the attainment of non-perception, the attainment of cessation, the karmic maturation of non-perception, the life faculty, the similarity of species, birth, aging, duration, impermanence, the collection of names, the collection of phrases, the collection of syllables, the nature of being an ordinary person, evolution, determination, association, speed, sequence, time, place, number, combination, and so forth.
What is acquisition? It is the temporary establishment of attainment and possession regarding wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate dharmas when they increase or decrease.
What is the attainment of non-perception?

It is the temporary establishment of the attainment of non-perception, based on the intention to escape, preceded by the thought of liberation, in the cessation of the inconstant mind and mental factors, for one who has already abandoned the desire for the pure abodes but not the desire for the higher [realms].
What is the attainment of cessation?

It is the temporary establishment of the attainment of cessation, based on the intention to temporarily stop [the activities of] the mind and mental factors, preceded by the thought of tranquility, in the cessation of the inconstant mind and mental factors and a part of the constant [mind and mental factors], for one who has already abandoned the desire for the sphere of nothingness and has transcended the summit of existence.
What is the karmic maturation of non-perception?

It is the cessation of the non-perpetually active mind and mental factors in those who have already been born among the gods of non-perception, provisionally established as the karmic maturation of non-perception.
What is the life faculty?
It is the determination of the duration of existence for a class of beings, provisionally established by the power of past karma.
What is a class of beings?
It is the similarity of individual beings of a certain kind, provisionally established as a class of beings.
What is birth?
It is the non-existence of conditioned factors in a class of beings, provisionally established as birth.
What is aging?
It is the change in the continuity of conditioned factors in a class of beings, provisionally established as aging.
What is duration?
It is the non-disruption of the continuity of conditioned factors in a class of beings, provisionally established as duration.
What is impermanence?
It is the disruption of the continuity of conditioned factors in a class of beings, provisionally established as impermanence.
What is a name-set?
It is conventionally established as a name aggregate with regard to the supernumerary words for the intrinsic nature of dharmas.
What is a sentence aggregate?
It is conventionally established as a sentence aggregate with regard to the supernumerary words for the distinctions of dharmas.
What is a syllable aggregate?
It is conventionally established as a syllable aggregate with regard to the letters that are the basis of those two.
This is called a syllable because it can manifest those two.
This is also called manifest because it can manifest that meaning.
This is also called a name because it does not change.
What is the nature of ordinary beings?
It is conventionally established as the nature of ordinary beings with regard to the non-attainment of the holy dharmas.
What is transmigration?
It is conventionally established as transmigration with regard to the uninterrupted continuity of causes and effects.
What is definite distinction?
It is conventionally established as definite distinction with regard to the various distinctions of causes and effects.
What is association?
It is conventionally established as association with regard to the correspondence of causes and effects.
What is speed?
It is conventionally established as speed with regard to the rapid transmigration of causes and effects.
What is sequence?
It is the establishment of sequence in the continuous transformation of causes and effects.
What is time?
It is the establishment of time in the continuous transformation of causes and effects.
What is direction?
It is the establishment of direction in the distinctions of causes and effects in the east, west, south, north, the four intermediate directions, above and below.
What is number?
It is the establishment of number in the distinctions of each and every existence.
What is aggregation?
It is the establishment of aggregation in the gathering of the various conditions of causes and effects.
How is the aggregate of consciousness established?
It is the distinction of mind, thought, and consciousness.
What is mind?
It is the store consciousness perfumed by the aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields, with all the seeds.
It is also called the consciousness of retribution, and also called the appropriating consciousness, because it is able to accumulate all perfuming.
What is thought?

That is, at all times it takes the Älaya consciousness as its object and has the nature of reflection and judgment. It is always associated with four passions, namely, view of a self, self-love, conceit in self, and ignorance.

This manas functions in all good, bad, and morally neutral states, with the exception of the state in which the holy path is present, or in states of the samÄdhi of cessation, or in the stage of post-learning.
Also, the six consciousnesses have as their manas the consciousness that has just ceased.
What is consciousness?
It is the group of the six consciousnesses.
They are visual, auditory, olfactory, taste, tactile, and mental consciousnesses.
What is visual consciousness?
It is the faculty of discriminating that which is based on the eye and is conditioned by the dharmas of form.
What is auditory consciousness?
It is the faculty of discriminating that which is based on the ear and is conditioned by the dharmas of sound.
What is olfactory consciousness?
It is the faculty of discriminating that which is based on the nose and is conditioned by the dharmas of smell.
What is taste consciousness?
It is the faculty of discriminating that which is based on the tongue and is conditioned by the dharmas of taste.
What is tactile consciousness?
It is the faculty of discriminating that which is based on the body and is conditioned by the dharmas of touch.
What is mental consciousness?
It is the nature of mental consciousness to depend on the mind, take dharmas as its object, and discriminate.
How are the realms established?

The form aggregate is the ten realms: eye realm and form realm, ear realm and sound realm, nose realm and smell realm, tongue realm and taste realm, body realm and touch realm, and part of the mind realm. The feeling aggregate, perception aggregate, and formation aggregate are part of the dharma realm. The consciousness aggregate is the seven consciousness realms, namely the six consciousness realms of eye, etc., and the mind realm.
What dharmas are not included in the aggregates?
It refers to the unconditioned dharmas in the dharma realm.

These unconditioned dharmas are of eight kinds: the suchness of wholesome dharmas, the suchness of unwholesome dharmas, the suchness of indeterminate dharmas, space, non-analytical cessation, analytical cessation, immovable, and cessation of perception and feeling.
What is the suchness of wholesome dharmas?
It refers to the nature of non-self, also called emptiness, signlessness, the ultimate reality, the ultimate truth, and the dharma realm.
Why is suchness called suchness?
Because its own-nature is without change.
Why is suchness called the nature of non-self?
Because it is apart from the two kinds of self.
Why is suchness called emptiness?
Because it is not the domain of all defilements.
Why is suchness called signlessness?
Because all signs are quiescent.
Why is suchness called the ultimate reality?
Because it is the nature of the object of non-error.
Why is suchness called the supreme truth?
Because it is the domain of the supreme holy wisdom.
Why is suchness called the dharma realm?
Because it is the characteristic that is the basis of the wonderful dharma of all Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and buddhas.
Just as the suchness of good dharmas, the suchness of bad dharmas and indeterminate dharmas should also be known in the same way.
What is space?
It refers to the nature of non-form, because it accommodates all activities.
What is non-analytical cessation?
It is cessation that is not liberation.
What is analytical cessation?
It is cessation, it is disjunction.
What is unshakable?
It is the cessation of pain and pleasure, for one who has already abandoned desire for the sphere of unlimited purity but has not yet abandoned desire for the higher sphere.
What is the cessation of perception and feeling?

It is the cessation of the non-perpetually active mind and mental factors, and the cessation of a part of the perpetually active mind and mental factors, due to the prior intention to suspend perception and feeling, for one who has already abandoned desire for the sphere of nothingness and has transcended the summit of existence.

Moreover, the five kinds of form, the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation, and the eight unconditioned dharmas as explained above - these sixteen are collectively called the dharma realm.
How are the sense bases established?
The ten form realms are the ten form sense bases, the seven consciousness realms are the mind sense base, and the dharma realm is the dharma sense base.

By this principle, the three dharmas of the aggregates, sense bases, and elements are all included, namely the form aggregate, the dharma realm, and the mind sense base.ğŸ”½As it is said, if there is an eye, is there also an eye element?
If there is an eye element, is there also an eye?
There may be eyes that are not eye-elements, namely, the last eyes of an arhat.

There may be eye-elements that are not eyes, namely, when dwelling in the egg-shell, in the kalala stage, in the arbuda stage, in the peÅ›in stage, in the ghana stage, in the praÅ›ÄkhÄ stage, in the mother's womb, if one does not obtain eyes, or even if one obtains them, they are lost;
Or if one is born in the formless realm, one has the causes of eyes.
There may be eyes that are also eye-elements, namely, in the remaining states.
There may be no eyes and no eye-elements, namely, those who have entered nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, and noble ones born in the formless realm.
Just as the eyes and the eye-elements, so should the ears, nose, tongue, body, and the ear, etc. elements be understood accordingly.
If there is mind, is there also mind-element?
If there is mind-element, is there also mind?
There may be mind that is not the mind-element, namely, the last mind of an arhat.
There may be the mind-element that is not mind, namely, the mind-causes of one dwelling in the concentration of cessation.
There may be mind that is also the mind-element, namely, in the remaining states.
Or there is no intention and no realm of mental objects, referring to those who have entered nirvÄá¹‡a without remaining support.
If one is born and grows in a certain stage, does one use the eye of that stage to see the forms of that stage?
Or one uses the eye of that stage to see the forms of that stage, or of another stage.
Referring to one born in the desire realm who uses the eye of the form realm to see the forms of the desire realm;
or using the eye of a higher stage of the form realm to see the forms of a lower stage.
As with the eye corresponding to form, so with the ear corresponding to sound.
As with being born in the desire realm, so with being born in the form realm.
If one is born and grows in the desire realm, one uses the nose, tongue, and body of the desire realm to smell, taste, and experience the smells, tastes, and tactile objects of the desire realm.
If one is born and grows in the form realm, one uses the body of the form realm to experience the tactile objects of one's own stage.
In that realm, by nature there are definitely no smells or tastes, because one is free from craving for gross food.
For this reason, there are also no nose and tongue consciousnesses.
If one is born in the desire realm, then with a desire realm mind one knows the dharmas of the three realms and the undefiled dharmas.
As with being born in the desire realm, so it is with being born in the form realm.

If one is born in the formless realm, with a formless mind one knows the formless dharmas of one's own stage and the undefiled dharmas, and if with an undefiled mind one knows the dharmas of the three realms and the undefiled dharmas.
Why are the aggregates arranged in this order?
Because of the abodes of consciousness, namely the four abodes of consciousness and consciousness.

Moreover, because the former are the support for the latter. Because one experiences according to the form of the object, because one cognizes according to the experience, because one thinks according to the cognition, and because one cognizes according to the thinking in each and every place.

Moreover, because of defilement and purification. That is to say, if one gives rise to defilement and purification in a certain place, if one is defiled or purified by means of experience, grasping characteristics, and fabrication, and that which is defiled and purified, for this reason the order of the aggregates is explained.
Why are the realms arranged in this order?
Because they arise in accordance with the distinctions of worldly affairs.
How do worldly affairs arise with distinctions?

It means that in the world, when people first meet each other, they greet each other. After greeting each other, they take baths, apply fragrances and flower garlands. Next, they enjoy various kinds of excellent food and drink. Next, they use various kinds of bedding and female attendants. Then, the mind realm distinguishes everywhere. Because the internal realms are arranged in order, the external realms are established. Following this order, the realms of consciousness are established.
Just as the realms are arranged in order, so are the sense bases.
What is the meaning of the aggregates?

All forms, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, are all briefly said to be one form aggregate, because of the meaning of accumulation, like an aggregate of wealth.
It is the same up to the aggregate of consciousness.
Moreover, they are called aggregates because the characteristic of suffering is extensive, like a large pile of wood.
As a sutra says:
Thus, the great mass of suffering arises.
Moreover, they are called aggregates because they bear the burden of defilements, like a shoulder bearing a burden.
What is the meaning of realm?
It means the seeds of all dharmas;
It also means being able to uphold one's own characteristics;
It also means being able to uphold the nature of causes and effects;
It also means the meaning of subsuming all dharmas.
What is the meaning of sense base?
The meaning of sense base is the door through which consciousness arises.
As the Buddha said:
Form is like a mass of foam, feeling is like a floating bubble, perception is like a mirage, mental formations are like a plantain tree, and consciousness is like an illusion.
For what meaning is form like a mass of foam, up to consciousness like an illusion?
Because of no self, because of being apart from purity, because of little taste, because of being unstable, and because of being unreal.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
